properties.name: Top Down Action Adventure Camera Example
properties.author: Silver-Streak

events.comment:
This example is designed to show how to accomplish a camera and room transition similar to many popular top down action RPGs or adventure games.
There is a requirement for a room-sized object for declaring the camera area. 
This should be stretched to the available area the character can walk in the same room, so the camera stays within the needed limits.
There should be a gap between each Room object so that the camera can transition between them. It is recommended that there be at least a 1 square gap around each room (so 2 squares between 2 rooms). Normally this means the room object would not cover the outer most walls. The rooms in this example are set up in that way to show how this works.
Set up IDs for each Room, to allow for detecting when the character has moved to a new room.

The camera and transitions function based off the player being inside a single room, represented by the CameraRoom object. The ID of the current room the character is in is constantly updated as an object variable.

Camera should stay motionless when in a single-screen sized room, or follow the player (within the room limits) in a larger room.
When moving between rooms, the camera should scroll up/down/left/right to the new room.

The formula in the camera is using a lerp expression. The speed of the transition can be adjusted by changing the last number (0.2)
The more important portion of that expression is the middle clamp() expression:
   The clamp is saying to use the Character's (X or Y) position as the camera IF it is at least the current room's center. 
   As the minimum position, It calculates this by taking the CameraRoom's origin point (CameraRoom.X/Y()), subtract the size of an extra square (16) to account for the extra wall around the room, then adds half the game resolution (stored as a global variable) to that total.
   The maximum position is similar, but adds (instead of subtracts) the extra square (16), the width/height of the room, then subtracts (instead of adds) half the game resolution
Whenever the character is not in the same room as the last stored "Active" room, start the transition.
While the transition is occurring, keep the current camera position updated as a variable. As cameras move on floating points (not integers), we round the coordinates.

If the camera's position is the same as the previously stored camera position, then the camera isn't moving anymore, meaning the transition is finished. 
Update the active room and end the transition.
Now that the OldCam variables has been used with the value of the last frame, put the values of the current frame inside them for the next frame.

Disable the character controls and maximize deceleration to stop the player immediately whenever a transition is occuring. Set the time scale to 0 to stop enemies and animations, then 1 to restart it.
This can be used as a way to stop/freeze enemies, such as by changing a variable to 1, and requiring all enemy logic to have that variable be 0. Likewise this same logic could be used to disable custom controls if default controls are not being used.
This is just an event to handle top-down collisions.
